articles.headline: For Elderly, Echoes of World War II Horrors
articles.snippet: “I lived through the Sendai air raids,” said Hirosato Wako, 75. “But this is much worse.”
articles.abstract: “I lived through the Sendai air raids,” said Hirosato Wako, 75. “But this is much worse.”
articles.lead_paragraph: NATORI, Japan — Hirosato Wako stared at the ruins of his small fishing hamlet: skeletons of shattered buildings, twisted lengths of corrugated steel, corpses with their hands twisted into claws. Only once before had he seen anything like it: World War II.

articles.headline: Many Culprits in Fall of a Family Film
articles.snippet: “Mars Needs Moms” is shaping up as a miss so disastrous that it will send signals to broad swaths of Hollywood.
articles.abstract: “Mars Needs Moms” is shaping up as a miss so disastrous that it will send signals to broad swaths of Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the movie business, sometimes a flop is just a flop. Then there are misses so disastrous that they send signals to broad swaths of Hollywood. “Mars Needs Moms” is shaping up as the second type.

articles.headline: Disaster in Japan Batters Suppliers
articles.snippet: The disaster in Japan has damaged factories and disrupted the power and transportation infrastructure, causing a jump in prices for electronic components.
articles.abstract: The disaster in Japan has damaged factories and disrupted the power and transportation infrastructure, causing a jump in prices for electronic components.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, chips that store eight gigabytes of data — for digital cameras, smartphones and other devices — cost as little as $7.30 each on the spot market, where many manufacturers buy components. On Monday, the cost was around $10.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Emerging Economies Move Ahead With Nuclear Plans
articles.snippet: Big developing nations might reconsider their ambitious plans. But for now India and China say they will continue to invest in nuclear power.
articles.abstract: Big developing nations might reconsider their ambitious plans. But for now India and China say they will continue to invest in nuclear power.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Despite Japan’s crisis, India and China and some other energy-ravenous countries say they plan to keep using their nuclear power plants and building new ones.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Publisher Limits Shelf Life for Library E-Books
articles.snippet: As librarians push for access to more e-books, publishers are reconsidering how much that access should be worth.
articles.abstract: As librarians push for access to more e-books, publishers are reconsidering how much that access should be worth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine the perfect library book. Its pages don’t tear. Its spine is unbreakable. It can be checked out from home. And it can never get lost.

articles.headline: Certainties of Modern Life Upended in Japan
articles.snippet: Tokyo residents are learning that things they have taken for granted can quickly slip beyond their reach.
articles.abstract: Tokyo residents are learning that things they have taken for granted can quickly slip beyond their reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan, a country lulled by the reassuring rhythms of order and predictability, has been jolted by earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis into an unsettling new reality: lack of control.

articles.headline: Libyan Forces Rout Rebels as West’s Effort for No-Flight Zone Stalls
articles.snippet: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi routed insurgents in Ajdabiya, their last defensive line before the rebel capital of Benghazi.
articles.abstract: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi routed insurgents in Ajdabiya, their last defensive line before the rebel capital of Benghazi.
articles.lead_paragraph: AJDABIYA, Libya — Behind tanks, heavy artillery and airstrikes, forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi routed a ragtag army of insurgents and would-be revolutionaries who were holding the last defensive line before the rebel capital of Benghazi on Tuesday.

articles.headline: World Markets Dive as Investors Retreat to Safety
articles.snippet: Japan’s nuclear disaster, the latest blow to the global growth prospects, led to heavy selling in equities.
articles.abstract: Japan’s nuclear disaster, the latest blow to the global growth prospects, led to heavy selling in equities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial aftershocks from the earthquake in Japan gathered force on Tuesday as investors fled from riskier assets like stocks, oil and gold amid growing worries that the crisis could slow a global economy that only recently seemed to be getting back on its feet.
